content:
The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, software for filing reports, limits on soft money of national political party committees, judicial review, and an increase in contribution limits. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, software for filing reports, limits on soft money of national political party committees, judicial review, an increase in contribution limits, prohibition of solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings, update of penalty amounts, and filing of Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require additional monthly and year-end reports from principal campaign committees. Monthly reports are due by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December. Quarterly reports are also required, with specific instructions for the treasurer. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require quarterly reports to be filed by the treasurer not later than the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. Additionally, a national committee of a political party must file the reports required under subparagraph (B). The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" requires monthly reports to be filed by the treasurer, amending the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Sections 304 and 309 of the Act are amended to change quarterly reports to monthly reports. SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. Political committees must separately itemize reporting for any person who contributes over $200 in a calendar year. The amended Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 requires political committees to report receipts and disbursements during the reporting period, with separate itemization for individuals contributing over $200 in a calendar year. Reports must be filed in the same manner and time periods as required for political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103. INCREASED ELECTRONIC DISCLOSURE. The Commission must make reports submitted under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 available on the Internet within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104. PUBLIC ACCESS TO BROADCASTING RECORDS. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 requires licensees to maintain and provide public access to records of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. This includes requests made by or on behalf of candidates for public office or messages concerning national legislative issues. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 mandates licensees to keep records of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance. The record includes details such as acceptance or rejection of the request, rate charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, candidate's name and office sought, election or issue referenced. The communication must include details such as the candidate's name, authorized committee, treasurer, and in the case of other requests, the purchaser's information and a list of key personnel. This information must be promptly placed in a political file and retained by the licensee. Information under this subsection must be promptly placed in a political file and retained by the licensee for a minimum of 2 years. SEC. 105. SOFTWARE FOR FILING OF REPORTS. The Commission shall develop software for filing reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act and provide it at no cost to those required to file. Users must use this software for filing reports. SEC. 201. LIMIT ON SOFT MONEY OF NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Amendment to Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to impose limits on soft money contributions by national political party committees. The text outlines limitations on donations to political party committees, restricting the amount to $60,000 per person per calendar year. Additionally, there is an aggregate limit on donors, preventing individuals from making disbursements exceeding $60,000 in a calendar year. Adjustments for inflation are also mentioned for amounts after 2001. In 2001, the $60,000 donation limit per person per calendar year will be adjusted for inflation based on the price index. The adjusted amount will be effective for that calendar year. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. (a) Expedited Review.--Any Member of Congress, candidate, national committee of a political party, or any person affected by section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 may bring an action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for declaratory judgment and injunctive relief on the grounds of constitutionality.
(b) Appeal to Supreme Court.--Orders of the District Court regarding actions under subsection (a) are directly appealable to the Supreme Court within specific timeframes. Expedited consideration and enforcement procedures for actions brought under section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, with the District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court expediting the disposition of such matters. The enforcement of section 324 is stayed from the filing of an action until final disposition by the Supreme Court. This section applies only to specific cases. The Supreme Court of the United States will review actions filed under this section within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in Individual and Political Committee Contribution Limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, with amendments raising limits from $1,000 to $3,000, $20,000 to $60,000, $5,000 to $15,000, and $25,000 to $75,000. Additionally, the second sentence in paragraph (3) is removed. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The amendments raise limits to $7,500, $30,000, and $15,000, with an additional provision for national party committees exceeding $15,000 in aggregate contributions to candidates. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The amendments raise limits to $7,500, $30,000, and $15,000, with an additional provision for national party committees exceeding $15,000 in aggregate contributions to candidates. Section 315(c) is amended to adjust limitations annually based on percentage differences. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The amendments raise limits annually and for a 2-year period for certain subsections. Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees are also increased. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees, including Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees. The amendments raise limits annually and for a 2-year period for certain subsections, with effective dates starting after December 31, 2001. TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 301. PROHIBITION OF SOLICITATION OF POLITICAL PARTY SOFT MONEY IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS. Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define "contribution" as a gift, subscription, loan, advance, or deposit of money made in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. Section 602(a)(4) of title 18 is also amended to include a prohibition on donations. Section 602(a)(4) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to replace the reference to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 with a new definition of contribution as defined in section 607(c). SEC. 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust penalty amounts for inflation based on the price index. This adjustment applies to calendar years after 2001. SEC. 303 requires Senate reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require all designations, statements, and reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. Conforming amendments are made to various sections to reflect this change.
